Award.AwardTitle: Atomic Layer Deposition for Large-Area Sub-10 Nanometer Patterning for Super Absorbing Optical Devices

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Nanomanufacturing is an important driving force for many applications, including nanomaterials, nanoelectronics, and nanophotonics. In the past decades, we have witnessed significant advances in nanomanufacturing capabilities. Different pre-designed patterns down to nanometer scale can be fabricated using various top-down and bottom-up methods. However, it is still a great challenge to manufacture nanostructures with sub-10 nanometer features over large areas using conventional fabrication techniques. Such small-scale structures are needed for the development of new applications. Using nano-scale antenna structures, localized optical field enhancements or 'hot-spots' are possible. Smaller gaps between the metallic nanopatterns will result in stronger 'hot spots'. Therefore, an affordable manufacturing method for large-area nanopatterning with sub-10 nanometer features is highly desirable. This award will employ the atomic layer deposition process to develop an inexpensive nanomanufacturing method to fabricate surface nanopatterns with accurately controlled gaps that can efficiently concentrate light field down to sub-10 nanometer scales over large areas. This interdisciplinary effort will link nanomanufacturing, computational electromagnetics, optoelectronics and optical sensing, and will provide a great opportunity for students to develop skills, values, and broad perspectives necessary for success in the global marketplace and for leadership in complex, multidisciplinary projects.

Building on recent successes in light management using nanostructures, this award will explore the potential to use this new nanomanufacturing method to fabricate super absorbing metamaterial surface structures or metasurfaces with controllable, ultra-narrow (sub-10nm) gaps. Specifically, this award will explore affordable fabrication processes to produce metallic nanopatterns with controllable separation distances defined by atomic layer deposited (ALD) dielectric films with the thickness accuracy of ~0.1nm. Such a capability will result in revolutionary advances in light-matter interactions at extremely deep subwavelength scales. Combined with pre-designed metamaterial cavity structures, incident light can be trapped within the nanogaps efficiently, resulting in a strongly enhanced localized field. By controlling the geometric parameters of nanopatterns, especially the gap dimension, the ultimate limit for plasmonic enhancement may be approached and be characterized conveniently over large areas. In this project, ALD-defined films will be combined with periodic and random nanopatterns to manufacture large area super absorbing metasurfaces, which will enable the development of novel on-chip energy collection, conversion and biosensing applications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
It has been reported that the optical field can be concentrated into deep-subwavelength volumes and realize significant localized-field enhancement (so called 'hot spot') using a variety of nanoantenna structures and is promising to develop enhanced nonlinear optics, surface photoctalysis and vibrational biosensing spectroscopies. It is generally believed that smaller gaps between metallic nanopatterns will result in stronger localized field enhancment (i.e. hot spots) due to optically driven free electrons coupled across the gap. However, it is a great challenge to manufacture very large-area sub-10-nm features using conventional top-down or bottom-up techniques. Therefore, an affordable manufacturing method for large-area nanopatterning of sub-10-nm-features is highly desired, which may introduce revolutionary advances in light-matter interaction within extremely deep subwavelength scales and pave the way towards light manipulation within quantum regime.

The key outcomes of this 3-year effort comprise fundamental scientific contributions across fields, ranging from nanomanufacturing, electromagnetic modeling to optical sensing. More specifically, we first designed super absorbing metasurface with periodic sub-5-nm gaps and demonstrated its application for surface enhanced infrared absorption spectroscopy. This observation demonstrated the predicted boosted light-matter interaction within extremely small gaps. Second, we manufactured super absorbing metasurfaces by combining random metallic nanoparticles with nanocavity architectures and demonstrated dispersive topological darkness phenomenon to realize strong optical absorption over a very broad band in visible to near infrared domain. This result revealed the spectral tunability of the light trapping structures with nanogaps. Third, we investigated the high yield manufacturing procedure to realize nanogaps for random metallic patterns over large area. This manufacturing method will enable the development of practical applications. Building upon the progress of these nanostructures, we demonstrated enhanced sensing of cocaine, biomolecules and enhanced heat assisted magnetic recording. This project resulted in 17 publication in prestigious journals including Advanced Science, Nano Energy, Science Advances, Advanced Optical Materials, etc. In particular, 5 papers were featured as the front cover articles by Advanced Optical Materials, Small Methods and Global Challenges (please refer to the uploaded figures with the final report). The sensitive sensing of cocaine was reported by BBS and Mirror, received significant public interests. We filed a provisional disclosure, aiming to seek the opportunities to commercialize the nanostructure manufactured by the method developed in this program. This 3-year project links experiences and expertise of faculties and graduate students across different fields of nanomanufacturing, photonic materials optics and photonics, quantum mechanics, and mathematical physics. We trained 2 PhD students and supported 6 undergraduate students using the REU supplementary award over the summer 2018 and 2019, including two female students and one Spanish scholar.
